Replies.Reply: Fall back into the woods! Out of your saddles before you're shot out of 'em!
DOWN!
Cole! Bob! You boys okay?

Charge!

Ah.

-- Exactly. Because this is a war.
It's not a bank.
Twenty?!

I shouldn't tease a hero.
Everybody in the county knows it was you who rescued Cole. We're all so proud of you, Jesse. And not a single farm's been sold to the railroad since. You're everybody's hero.
So you're saying I should leave you alone and go spend time with Jimmy Younger?
Why thank you, Bob.
You didn't want to farm?
A river pirate.
Thank God you grew out of that.
You did grow out of that, didn't you?
You planning on being a bachelor your whole life, Jesse James?
And what's this right girl like?
Where will you find such a girl?
Sparkling rocks?
Is this one of Frank's Shakespeare poems you're trying to quote?
Were you planning on kissing me when you finished quoting?
I am so sorry, Jesse.
You and I, we've started...
Let the law --
Whose justice? Yours or God's?
When will you stop?
He thinks this is some kind of game!
Jesse. What are you thinking? There are bounty hunters and lawmen all over this county!
I don't understand.
That's... wonderful. It's just... I thought...
I would never have imagined us in a place like this.
Are you going to be happy here, Mr.
Now wait a minute. There are certain things that have to wait until after the wedding.
Hmm.
"But the life of the James Gang wasn't all robbing and shooting and killing, for these young Missouri bucks had a taste for the ladies...
"Blazing Guns of the West. True Stories of Jesse James." Only a dime in the hotel lobby.
Oh, I'm not finished.
"When he sauntered into a saloon, his spurs jangling and his pockets full of gold, the ladies flocked around him like flies to a candied apple."
As I said. Hmm.
Jesse, have you ever noticed that when you're trying to charm your way out of trouble, your accent gets all farm boy?
Stop it. This is just sad.
Don't turn around.
If you don't see it, it's not real...
Thank you. Now go get my husband.
You get arrested again, I'll kill you.
I can't believe I had to blow up a train for you.
Don't swear.
Tennessee?
Frank, Jesse.
Where's Web?
My little Web did that?
Web died fighting?
Start thinking about yourselves.
For soldiers, yes. But if you rode in one of the partisan bands, they'll hang you for treason. And you boys are in more danger, because you've got a farm.
Zerelda, it's no coincidence. The railroad men come through, offering to buy up land. Nobody sells. Then they start hanging men who own farms for treason?
Rich men in Washington, don't matter if they wear a tie or a uniform, they're all the same.
Now go on to see your Ma. She'll be glad to see her sons alive.
And for her sake, stay that way.
Floor recognizes Clell Miller.
Loni Packwood.
Ah, Loni, about the railroad.
Boys...
The bullet came out clean, but he lost a whole lot of blood. Praying wouldn't hurt.
A fugitive? Who?
They're gone. What are you --
Well, I hope the boy pulls through.
Go on. You're pretty much all healed up.
You know you're welcome any time!
It's fine by me, Jesse.
Why, that hadn't even occurred to me, Frank. I am deeply in your debt.
"...written by the outlaw Jesse James himself."
I'm upset too, Zee, but Jesse and Cole know what they're doing. I'm sure they won't press their luck.
I know. But the Lord protects madmen and prophets, and Jesse's...one of them. I'm just not sure which.
My boys! My boys!
My boys are alive!
Did you kill Yankees?
Say your prayers?
Good. Now get inside and wash up for dinner.
I don't see clean plates.
He's a good Christian and he killed Yankees. Jesus told me that made him an all right boy.
We're just fine, thank you, sir.
Two dollars?
This land ain't for sale.
Let me ask the Lord.
The Lord says we can bury 'em out back in the orchard, nobody'll ever find them.
Oh all right.
Riders --
Take care of each other, boys. You say your prayers.
Shush.
Well look at that. The Good Lord's a bit shorter than I reckoned.
Mmmph-hmpph.
It's my fault they're gonna hang Cole. I want in.
I'm the same age you were when you went off to war.
Is that bad?
I like that.
That's a great plan, Jesse!
Where do we hit first, Jesse?
Hold on there, sir. Bank's closed today.
Bank holiday! Bank's closed!
Ow! Ow!
Ow!
I think Jesse's got a good idea --
We're famous!
We made history. That's something to be proud of.
I never thought that posse was gonna give up.
I kinda like the sound of the James-Younger Gang.
How about "James-Younger" for the bank jobs and "Younger-James" for the train robberies?
You okay, Jesse?
Not too young to shoot a man, not to young to drink.
I was always jealous Web Mimms got to go off and fight with you and Cole. Now it's my turn.
Tonight? Why, I'm just getting ready to turn on the Younger charm.
Well, not exactly.
Hell yeah! I been with...
Uh, not exactly. It's just, I don't want to get one of these paid ladies, you know?
You and Frank and Cole, and even Bob, get all these girls because you're good looking and famous. You don't have to pay. They just look at me like I'm the baby brother.
Don't tell anyone, okay Jesse?
Tell you something else.
I can't drink that good neither.
Why, yeah.
Oh, you were talking to Jesse.
Really?
Not at all.
Thank you, Miss -- ?
Gosh, that's a pretty name. Buy you a drink?
Why don't we get a bottle of sherry to sip while we talk?
Devereux. My brother Cole dated a European girl once.
Don't talk about it much, though.
And you both hate the railroad.
It's his money.  He's putting up the payroll out of his own fortune.
Look!
... too young for whisky...
Jesse, you explain to Lyla. My girl, you know, from that time...
Best time of my life.
I was famous, y'know...
Howdy, folks. How are you this afternoon?

I am Rollin H. Parker, personal emissary of Mr. Thaddeus Rains, president of the Rock Island and Pacific Railroad. These two gentlemen are Pinkerton detectives, working for Mr. Thaddeus Rains, president of the Rock Island and Pacific Railroad, and this gentleman here is the famous Alan Pinkerton, founder of the Secret Service and now working under contract to Mr.
As you have no doubt heard from your neighbors, our railroad is moving west.
... moving west, opening the frontier for folks such as yourself.
I'm here for your signature on this land sales contract. I'm authorized to pay you two dollars an acre.
That's right. That's the price authorized by the railroad's board, and approved by the Department of the Interior of the Government of the United States of America.
I'm doing you folks a favor --
-- with a price of two dollars an acre for this one time only offer.
Ma'am. You have to look in your heart and do what you know is right here.
You people are making a serious mistake!
Relax, Alan. The Army has this all in hand. And Mr. Thaddeus Rains will be very pleased with this news.
Mr. Thaddeus Rains, sir, it is a pleasure to have you join us in the field.
Really!
I can completely understand your distress, sir.
Two weeks ago, we managed to arrange to have the Army hang one of the local farmers.

Unfortunately not, sir. A gang of local thugs managed to rescue him from the gallows. Not only has this inspired resistance from the other farmers, the redoubtable Mr. Alan Pinkerton was seriously injured during the incident.
Yes sir.
A further impediment is that the Army garrison has been ordered to move on from Liberty. We will no longer have that particular stick with which to threaten the farmers.
I see. I'll get together four patrols of our detectives for action tonight.
They exchanged fire with the Pinkerton Guards, killing several of them. Then they raided the payroll office and blew the tracks for half a mile.
Thirty-five thousand, sir. Coins and currency. And the delay from the miles of destroyed track --
To be precise, they didn't blow up the tracks.
We did.
... I mean, our men. Our own workers planted the dynamite.
They were under duress.
Your men knew the risks.
They had to be dealt with!
What about your detectives? They haven't --
How can that be?
We should go burn that school to the ground, sir!
The final route for the railroad is complete.
Sir?
What, sir?
Oh, that. I'll let Jenkins explain.
I remember you.
How did you know?
There's only four of them...
Ma'am, I can understand how you might feel that way -- you've made a lovely home here. But it's really not up to me or you. Are you familiar with the legal concept of the Right of Eminent Domain?
Well, this land is about to be condemned.
I don't think you understand. You don't have a choice.
Nicely played.
It's not my job to relax. I've put men facing out both ways down Main Street, so nobody can ride in shooting. I've got a sharpshooter up on the water tower just in case.
Brilliant...
Not to mention my men who lost their lives.
My professional opinion is that you have managed to piss off the wrong bunch of farm boys this time.
By burning down their homes?
Oh no, I would have done that. But I would have made sure I killed them, too.
Would a jury around here convict their own? I think not. We're beginning an interesting game here, Mr. Rains.
I'm afraid our adversaries don't agree.
It is a nice piece of writing.
Oh, that's the best part.
It's early in the game yet, Mr.
Hardly farmers. I've done some checking. All these were in the War.
It's going to be a long winter.
All of the James Gang's encounters have been with local law enforcement who, quite frankly, are no match for this group's cunning.
First of all: you, shut up.

Now, you've given me a thousand miles of railroad to cover. Every time the James Gang strikes, we shift a hundred detectives to that area. But there's just too much open land, too many riverbeds to ride, caves to hide in. This gang operates across four states, often riding a hundred miles between jobs.
And there are some towns in Missouri where James and his men can walk openly, as heroes.
They donate money to farmers, to churches. Rumor has it they gave the sharecroppers of Maddox so much money they were able to build a school.
Yes, that's the way to win the locals back to our side.
You want this fool to saddle up and take another run at it?
It's going to be a long spring.
Every three months, the James Gang circles back to the vicinity of Liberty, Missouri. They always pull a job right before they return, probably to have extra money to give family and friends.
There are only four banks within that travel radius which they have not robbed.
No need. I have another tool at my disposal which will narrow it down to one bank.
Why, their intense hatred of you, of course.
Jesse James, you are under arrest!
We're moving you tomorrow.
Oh, it's a similar room. But the hotel is in Washington D.C. You're not going to get a fair trial down here, in front of a jury of Jesse James sympathizers.
That's the idea.
Not that day. I am guilty of many things, but that was Mr. Thaddeus Rains and Parker, that day.
Was this you, by the way?
Pity.
How did you spot the ambush in Torrell?
Mmm.
Yes?
Damn.
I went myself to oversee the operation. Didn't help much.
Oh. That's nice to know.
We're going to hang you, you know.
Was it worth it?
That's what I would have done.
You cocky little bastard.
No, I'll hang you.
But I may miss you just a bit.
If you feel that way, I could always take off the irons.
Hook him up.
Now the guns.

In the ten seconds we have been in this car, I have seen you get close enough for Jesse James to grab your guns at least three times. And I assure you, if he gets his hands on one of your guns, you are all, and I mean all dead men.
I'll put that on your tombstone.
Vengeance.
Outside! Get up on top! Go GO!
Move you fools!
Do it.
He's too important, James.  They'll set the army on you. You and your wife.
Tennessee.
The railroad has no business in Tennessee. Therefore I have no interest in the state of Tennessee.
I'd just as soon kill you, Jesse James. But chasing you takes up too much of my time.
They're saying we don't sell, we might end up with nothing!
Maybe we should hire a lawyer.
So what do we do?
What do we do?
None of them risked their necks for this.
This ain't no war.
Nobody paid me no thousand dollars to fight in the War!
We only got ten thousand.
Damn, Loni, you're lucky.
You have got mighty full of yourself lately, Jesse.
That's a long ride, Cole. We won't be back 'til morning.
We can't exactly go back to our lives, Jesse.
I say this is the last straw. I came back from the war, I found my house burned down. My cows was dead.
I forget.
Took my dog...
My luck is changing at last!
What are the odds, another gang robbing the same place right after we did.
Lucky Rabbit's foot. Took it off that dead fella over there.
Luckiest man in the West, now that I'm riding with Jesse James!
I signed.
I'm tired of fighting. I'm just gonna take my family and move west.
That's a good idea!
Sir, are you all right?
Somebody get a doctor!
Good evening, sir, we're looking for a fugitive.
We don't know, but he was very badly wounded. We're checking all the houses in the area.
Oh. Sorry ma'am.
And it is my pleasure to be here.

NO! It is NOT my pleasure to have to leave my board room to come to this godforsaken piece of dirt to discover why in the name of all that is holy you cannot seem to evict a few simple farmers from their PATHETIC LITTLE MUDHOLES so that I may build the GREATEST railroad that this country has ever seen!
Parker, tell me what's going on so I can return as quickly as possible to Boston and my whores and cigars, not necessarily in that order.
Good.
Leaving you in charge of operations until he recovers.
Just perfect.
You see the Army leaving and you see the loss of a tool. I see a power void to be filled. As we have the most power, we may move with impunity.
I'll teach these podunks what happens when they challenge the righteousness of progress.
How much did they get from the safe?
I'll kill them for blowing up my railway!
THEN WHO DID?!
Where the hell is Pinkerton?
Look at this, Pinkerton! They got the payroll, and this damage will set construction back two months at least.
What is going on here, man?
You wouldn't have done that?
I want them arrested and hanged!
This is no game.

"A Rock Island and Pacific Railroad depot was robbed two nights ago just outside St. Louis, Missouri. The brave and daring James-Younger Gang was heavily outnumbered by Pinkerton detectives, but the city lawmen were no match for the guns of the West."

"The gang made off with thirty-five thousand dollars and also destroyed the Thaxton Switch construction, meaning that for a few months honest farmers will be able to sleep without fearing the railroad is coming to steal their land!"
Who wrote this!? I'll see him hanged every Tuesday for a month!
Replies.Didascalie: (he slams the paper into Parker's chest)

Replies.Reply: "The foregoing article was sent to the newspaper. It was reputedly written by the outlaw --
Jesse James himself!"
Senator, can't you do anything?
Pinkerton, why can't you get these outlaws?
I'm losing millions of dollars and months of time while you play chess with these farmers!
So you can't tell me anything?
Pinkerton. It's been eight months.
I can't believe this.
With my money!
I demand action.
Can't you tell me anything?
I look forward to seeing it.
Parker.
What is that?
That.
Jenkins.
Jenkins.
So he's won.
In English, Pinkerton.
Can you put men at all four?
What is that?
This is him.
Not such a menace now, is he, Pinkerton?
You stole thousands. You cost me tens of millions of dollars, months of lost construction. I wish I could hang you every single morning for a century.

You like that? Solid gold, my father had it made when he started this railroad. He gave it to me when I took over, I'll give it to my son when he runs this company, and he'll give it to his son -- The right type of men will always run this country, Jesse James, and little men like you will always suffer. You have stopped nothing.
We'll speak again in Washington, you insect.
Big words.
What the hell is that sound?
What are you talking about? The railroad's money is right over there in that safe.
Ah.
This is outrageous. Who are you people?
Wha?
Get off me!
I know it ain't no durned bank holiday!
Then why can't I go in there?
Oh. Why didn't you just say so?
Fine. I'll just wait here.
Why?
What the --
Old Man Tucker is just standing quiet outside the bank.
When have you ever known Old Man Tucker not to be yelling at everybody?
Where the hell were you?
Shit.
What is it?
So?
I had you covered.
From back there.
Look at that.
"Better... slow... down...
Sir, this bill is counterfeit!
Of course!
Uh, sir?
Where is Jesse James?
All right, all right.
Jesse James never yelled at folk...
The people see the James-Younger Gang as heroes against the Eastern businessmen. This is not an area where men in suits are much loved.
Yeah, Injun. What do you want?
Of St. Louis?
East? East above the river heading for the Eagle Pass?
I want every man in town! We can cut off Jesse James before he crosses out of my territory! Let's go!
Go ahead to the saloon. But don't get too drunk!
Old "Wanted" posters are replaced by a new set.
Think nothing of it.
Better than you, Jesse?
Of course.
Excuse me. Are you Jim Younger?
I hope you don't mind, Jesse James told me your name.
Yes, but just so I could find out who you were.
I hope I'm not being too forward.
I just though you were awful cute.
Lyla Devereux.
Could we go upstairs and talk? It's so loud down here.
That is so gentlemanly of you.
Really?
Sir.
We've done a financial study of the construction costs projected into --
It's cheaper to go around Jesse James, sir. Even with the detour and the extra track. It's just cheaper.
What religion?
This is unusual. Most of our marriages are members of the congregation.
The Lord is remarkably tolerant of the charitable.
"Jesse Woodson James." Jesse James?
Discretion? Sir, I am a man of the cloth.
Who needs to repair a leaky church roof.
Now let's have a drink.
Communion.
But the Youngers ride with Jesse James.
I don't like it. We can handle him.
He's chained up.
What?
What you sayin' boy?
How?
You shut up now, boy.
Y'know, Uncle Frank...
...every time you tell that story, you stop there. That's not how it ended. I was five when my dad got shot.
Sounds like he was a hell of a man.
They're making him a hero now.
But he killed a lot of men, too.
So what was he?
